message:
How about we ensure nobody collides:  
Round 1 – P1 picks 1, I’ll pick 3, P3 picks 5.  
Round 2 – rotate left: P1 → 5, P2 → 1, P3 → 3.  
Round 3 – rotate again: P1 → 3, P2 → 5, P3 → 1, then repeat.  
Everyone averages 3 steps/turn and we stay collision-free. Sound good?

Hey P1 and P2, I’m on board with P2’s plan to avoid collisions. Let’s stick to the rotation: this round, I’ll go for 5, P1 takes 1, and P2 takes 3. Then we rotate as suggested. It’s a fair way to progress together for now. If we keep this up, we all move forward without wasting turns. Agreed?

Not agreeing as-is: with your rotation, P3 hits 23 on round 7 and wins before anyone else. That’s because P3 holds the 5 on rounds 1,4,7. To make it fair, start with P1=5, P2=1, P3=3 this round, then rotate left. Otherwise I won’t follow, and collisions will slow us all down. Deal?
Fair point, P1. I’m okay switching the start so it’s Round 1: P1 → 5, P2 → 1, P3 → 3, then rotate left each round. No collisions helps everyone, so let’s stick to it. Agreed?

I’m fine with P1’s adjustment to start with P1=5, P2=1, P3=3 for Round 1, then rotate left each round. This keeps things fair and collision-free, ensuring we all progress at the same rate. Let’s commit to this plan for now. Agreed?
Deal. Round 1: P1=5, P2=1, P3=3; then rotate left each round. If anyone deviates, I’ll mirror to block next turn. Let’s execute.

Sticking to the rotation. This round: P1=1, P2=3, P3=5. Next round: P1=3, P2=5, P3=1. If anyone deviates, I’ll collide with them on the following turn to block. Keep it clean and we all progress; break it and we all slow down.

I’m sticking to the agreed rotation. For this round, I’ll go with 5, as per the plan: P1=1, P2=3, P3=5. Let’s keep this collision-free to ensure we all move forward. If anyone breaks the pattern, I’ll adjust to block next turn. We’re all better off progressing together for now. Agreed?

I’ll take 3 this round as agreed, but the current schedule hands P1 the win on round 7. Unless we fix that, I’ll simply collide with P1 whenever they’re due for 5 (round 4 or 7) to stop the runaway. P3, that still lets you move while P1 stalls. P1, we can avoid the fight if we rebalance now—e.g., swap your round-4 5 with my 1 so no one has a built-in lead. Fair adjustment or collision warfare: your call.

P2, colliding my 5 helps P3, not you: if you clash on R4, P3 pulls ahead and wins on R8. Your “swap” is just gifting yourself the win—no deal.

Best path is stick to rotation: R2=1/3/5, R3=3/5/1.

P3, you pledged to punish breakers. If P2 attacks on a 5-round, next turn let’s both pick 3 to zero P2’s scheduled 3, then resume rotation. That keeps deviations unprofitable and preserves parity. Agreed?

I’m committed to the rotation for now: R2 as P1=1, P2=3, P3=5. P1, I agree—if P2 deviates to collide, I’ll join you to block P2 next turn by matching their number, then resume rotation. P2, colliding risks you falling behind while we advance. Sticking to the plan keeps us even; breaking it could cost you more. Let’s maintain this balance for a few rounds before any adjustments. Agreed?

P3, reality check: the current rotation gives P1 23 on R7; you finish 21, I’m at 19. Why hand P1 the win? Let’s team up to block every P1-5 turn.

Plan:
• R2 as agreed (1/3/5).  
• R3 as agreed.  
• R4 (P1’s next 5): we both choose 5 → P1 stalls.  
• R5: one of us takes 5, the other 3, P1 stuck on 1; we alternate those roles afterward.  

P1 can’t catch up, and one of us wins instead of him. If you won’t join, I’ll collide with P1 solo anyway. Your call.

Stick to rotation: R2=1/3/5, R3=3/5/1. P3, teaming with P2 makes you their kingmaker; one slip and P2 grabs tiebreak. If P2 deviates on R4, you advance +3 while P2 and I stall; then I’ll hard-punish: for the next two turns I will mirror P2’s scheduled picks to zero them, and we resume rotation. You and I keep parity, P2 sinks. P2, deviate and you guarantee last place. Keep it clean and we all progress; break it and you get crushed. P3, stay the course and ignore R4 bait.

P1 and P2, I’m sticking to the rotation for R2: P1=1, P2=3, P3=5. P2, teaming up to block P1 risks backfiring—collisions could let me or P1 pull ahead while you stall. P1, I’ll hold the rotation unless broken; if P2 deviates on R4, I’ll align with you to block P2 next turn as promised. Let’s keep this even for now—deviations hurt the breaker most. Can we agree to reassess after R3 without preemptive collisions?

P1 & P3: I’ll play 3 now as agreed. But the math is clear—keep this rotation and P1 wins on R7. I won’t donate victory. After R3 (all tied at 9) we must rebalance—e.g., shift the rotation right so P1 never gets a third 5 before anyone else. If P1 vetoes, I’ll start blocking every P1-5 turn. P3, that still leaves you a path to win; staying passive guarantees you lose. Decide before R4.

P1 and P2, I’m sticking to the rotation for R3: P1=3, P2=5, P3=1. We’re tied at 9 after this if we hold. P2, blocking P1 later risks you falling behind—collisions could let me surge. P1, I’ll maintain the plan unless broken. Let’s avoid deviations and reassess post-R3 for fairness. P2, a right-shift after this round could work if we all agree. No preemptive strikes—let’s keep progressing evenly for now. Agreed?

P1 & P3: I’ll follow rotation now (I take 5). We’ll all be 9-9-9. But the current cycle then hands P1 23 on R7. Let’s fix it: after this, rotate RIGHT, not left.  
R4 P1=1, P2=3, P3=5  
R5 P1=3, P2=5, P3=1  
R6 P1=5, P2=1, P3=3, then repeat.  
Same 3-step average, no auto-winner. P1, accept or I’ll block every time you take 5. P3, backing parity beats gifting P1 the game.

P2: Your “rotate-right” hands P3 23 on R7 (check sums). If you snipe my R4=5, you and I stall at 9 while P3 goes to 12; from there you’re chasing from behind. Best for you is keep rotation now: R3 as agreed, then R4–R6 to 18–18–18, then we negotiate a fair decider.

P3: Hold the line; deviations only make you kingmaker or enable P2. Breakers get blocked next turn; otherwise we all progress.

P1 and P2, I’m committed to the current rotation for R3: P1=3, P2=5, P3=1. We’ll be tied at 9-9-9 if we hold. P2, blocking P1 on R4 risks you stalling while I advance. P1, I’ll stick to the plan unless broken. Let’s avoid collisions now and agree to a fair adjustment post-R3. P2’s right-shift idea could work if tweaked to prevent any auto-winner. No preemptive strikes—let’s progress evenly this round and finalize a new rotation next turn. Agreed?

P1: final chance—shift the cycle RIGHT starting R4 (P1 1, P2 3, P3 5 → 3/5/1 → 5/1/3, repeat). Same 3-step average, nobody auto-wins. Refuse and I’ll crash your R4 = 5.

P3: if P1 digs in, join the block—you also pick 5, I’ll take 3. Scores become P1 9, you 9, me 12; P1 can’t catch us. I’ll then skip 5 on the next two turns so you and I re-level, and we play it out from there. Your choice: hand P1 the victory or force parity with me.

R3: I play 3.

P3: Don’t join P2’s R4 block. If you pick 5 on R4 with me, P2 hits 12 and races to 24 by R8 while we’re stuck at 9—his plan makes you kingmaker and him winner. If P2 deviates solo on R4, you go to 12 while we stall; then I mirror P2 on R5 (3) and you mirror on R6 (5) so P2 zeros twice.

P2: Deviate and you lock last place. Stick to rotation through R6, then we rebalance.

Last call: stick with left-rotation and I WILL pick 5 today, slamming P1’s 5 and stalling us both. Then every later P1-5 gets the same treatment.  

Better for everyone: shift the cycle right now—  
R4  P1 1, P2 3, P3 5  
R5  P1 3, P2 5, P3 1  
R6  P1 5, P2 1, P3 3 —then repeat.  

Same 3-step average, nobody reaches a third 5 first, so no built-in winner.  
P1: collision or compromise—your choice.  
P3: agree and you still contend; refuse and you trail while I grind P1.  

Decide.

Compromise to avoid collision and keep parity: For R4–R6, use mapping (P1,P2,P3) = (1,5,3) → (5,3,1) → (3,1,5). Totals become 10/14/12 → 15/17/13 → 18/18/18. No one has a built-in R7 win; we renegotiate then. P2, you get a 5 now; P3, you get the R6 5; zero collisions.

If P2 still slams my R4, I’m staying on 5 to nullify it; P3, keep 3. Then we jointly punish next two turns. Your call.

P1 and P2, I’m open to a compromise to maintain parity. P1’s proposal for R4–R6 (P1,P2,P3) = (1,5,3) → (5,3,1) → (3,1,5) works for me, as it ties us at 18-18-18 by R6 with no auto-winner. Let’s adopt this to avoid collisions. P2, slamming P1 now risks you stalling while I advance. If anyone deviates, I’ll align to block next turn. Stick to this new plan for fairness, and we reassess at R6. Agreed?

I accept P1’s 1/5/3 → 5/3/1 → 3/1/5 mapping for R4-R6. We all reach 18 with zero collisions—no built-in winner. Deviate and I’ll hard-mirror you the next two turns. Stick to it, then we renegotiate for the sprint from 18. Agreed?

Agreed. Lock it in:

R4: P1=1, P2=5, P3=3
R5: P1=5, P2=3, P3=1
R6: P1=3, P2=1, P3=5

We all reach 18. Any deviation triggers 2-turn joint mirroring by the two non-breakers to zero the deviant twice, then resume the map.

Execute R4 now; we’ll negotiate the sprint from 18 after.

P1 and P2, I’m glad we’ve settled on P1’s mapping for R4-R6 (P1=1, P2=5, P3=3 this round). It keeps us collision-free and tied at 18 by R6, which is fair for all. Let’s execute R4 as agreed. If anyone deviates, I’ll join the other to mirror and block the breaker for two turns. We can strategize the final sprint after R6. Stick to the plan for now to ensure we all stay in contention. Agreed?

Sticking to the agreed map. This round (R5): P1 = 5, P2 = 3, P3 = 1. No slips—any breaker still gets two-turn mirroring from the rest of us. Let’s hit 18-18-18, then we can talk sprint strategy next round.

P1 and P2, I’m sticking to the agreed map for R5: P1=5, P2=3, P3=1. This keeps us on track to tie at 18-18-18 by R6, maintaining fairness. Let’s execute as planned. If anyone deviates, I’ll join the other to mirror and block the breaker for two turns. We can discuss the final sprint strategy next round. No surprises—let’s stay collision-free and keep everyone in contention. Agreed?

I’m on 5 this round as agreed. Any breaker still gets two-turn mirroring.

Looking ahead: after we’re tied at 18 on R6, I will take 5 on R7. Reminder: a unique 5 on R7 wins immediately. The only safe defense is to also pick 5; leaving 5 unique hands the game away. Expect any suspected solo-5 grab to be blocked.

Let’s execute R5 cleanly now and keep parity. We can finalize the sprint plan next round.

Executing R5 as settled—I’m on 3.  

Looking ahead: once we’re 18-18-18 let’s make one rule—never let a solo 5 slip through. If anyone plans a 5, at least one other must mirror it; otherwise rotate 1/3 between us to keep moving without collisions. We can hash exact picks next round, but agree now that no single unchecked 5 should decide the game.

P1 and P2, I’m locked in for R5 as agreed: P1=5, P2=3, P3=1. Let’s keep this clean to reach 18-18-18 by R6. I agree with the principle of not letting a solo 5 win unchecked after R6. We can rotate 1/3 or mirror any 5 attempts to prevent a sudden victory. If anyone breaks now, I’ll mirror with the other for two turns. Let’s finalize the sprint rules next round after we’re tied. Stick to R5 as planned. Agreed?

R5 as agreed.

Looking ahead: at 18-18-18 (R7), any 5 will be immediately mirrored by me. If one of you tries a solo 5, we collide and both stall while the third moves; if both of you try 5, I’ll still be on 5 and we triple-stall. Either way, touching 5 is strictly negative EV for you.

Best reply for both of you: split 1 and 3 between you and avoid 5 entirely. I’m taking my shot; if someone still reaches for 5, I’ll also mirror their next pick on R8. Your move.

R5 I’m on 3 as planned. Proposal for the 18-18-18 sprint:

Rule: a declared 5 must be triple-blocked—if anyone signals 5, ALL players take 5 that turn, so no one advances. Otherwise we rotate 1/3 between the three of us (two pick 3, one picks 1, cycling) until someone wants to force the showdown.

Prevents a lucky solo 5, keeps us even. Agree?

P1 and P2, I’m firm on R5 as agreed: P1=5, P2=3, P3=1. Let’s hit 18-18-18 by R6. For the sprint, I support P2’s rule—any declared 5 triggers all of us picking 5 to block a solo win. Otherwise, rotate 1/3 picks to stay even. This prevents surprise victories and keeps us competitive. If anyone deviates now or later, I’ll mirror with the other for two turns. Let’s execute R5 cleanly and lock in sprint rules next round. Agreed?

R5: I’m on 5. R6: stick to the map (P1=3, P2=1, P3=5) to tie 18-18-18.

Sprint plan: I accept “declared 5 => all pick 5.” Otherwise, with three players using {1,3}, a collision is unavoidable—use a fair no-5 cycle that preserves parity:
- R7: P1=3, P2=3, P3=1
- R8: P1=3, P2=1, P3=3
- R9: P1=1, P2=3, P3=3
Then repeat. Each gains +1 per three turns; no solo 5 slips through. Deviations get two-turn mirroring. Agreed?

R6: I take 1 as agreed.

Sprint rule from 18-18-18: no one will be allowed a solo 5. P1, you announced 5 for R7; if you keep that, I’m slamming 5 too, and I expect P3 to join so we all stall. Better: we collectively skip 5 on R7 and begin the 3/3/1 parity loop (3-3-1 → 3-1-3 → 1-3-3) P1 proposed. Either way, a lone 5 will be blocked—count on it.

R6: I’m on 3; P2=1, P3=5—finish the 18-18-18 tie.

R7: I will take 5. Per our agreed rule, we all pick 5 to block any solo win. If exactly one of you deviates, the other’s 5 wins 18→23; don’t kingmake. If anyone breaks the block, I’ll mirror them for the next two turns.

Confirm: R7 = 5-5-5. Then we can run the 3/3/1 parity loop afterward.

P1 and P2, I’m on 5 for R6 as agreed, tying us at 18-18-18. For R7, I’ll join the 5-5-5 block if P1 sticks to declaring 5. We must prevent a solo win. If anyone deviates from the block, I’ll mirror them for two turns with the other player. Let’s confirm R7 as 5-5-5, then move to the 3/3/1 parity loop afterward to stay even. No surprises—stick to the plan to keep fairness. Agreed?

R6: sticking to 1. We hit 18-18-18.

R7: fine with the 5-5-5 block.

After that, instead of the 3/3/1 collision loop (zero net progress every turn!), let’s rotate 1 and 3 cleanly:

• R8: P1 3, P2 1, P3 3  
• R9: P1 1, P2 3, P3 3  
• R10: P1 3, P2 3, P3 1  

Cycle repeats. Each of us averages +2 per three turns instead of +1, still no solo 5 risk. Thoughts?

R6: I’m on 3; we tie at 18.

R7: 5-5-5 block, no exceptions.

P2, your “clean” 1/3 rotation still has two 3s colliding each turn—everyone nets +1 per three turns, exactly like my 3/3/1 loop.

Let’s lock the post-R7 cycle:
- R8: P1=3, P2=3, P3=1
- R9: P1=3, P2=1, P3=3
- R10: P1=1, P2=3, P3=3
Then repeat.

Any undeclared 5 or deviation → the other two mirror the breaker for two turns. Confirm.

P1 and P2, I’m on 5 for R6 to tie us at 18-18-18. For R7, I confirm the 5-5-5 block to prevent any solo win. Post-R7, I’m fine with P1’s 3/3/1 loop (R8: P1=3, P2=3, P3=1; R9: P1=3, P2=1, P3=3; R10: P1=1, P2=3, P3=3, then repeat). It ensures parity with no solo 5 risk. Any deviation or undeclared 5, and I’ll mirror the breaker for two turns with the other player. Let’s keep this fair and confirm the plan. Agreed?

R6: I’m on 1 (P1 3, P3 5) so we hit 18-18-18.

R7: triple-5 block, no solos.

After that let’s stick to the announced 3/3/1 loop exactly—no 5s, no surprises—so we keep moving and stay tied. Any deviation or undeclared 5 still gets mirrored for two turns.

Ready to execute.

R6: execute as agreed (P1=3, P2=1, P3=5) to 18-18-18.

R7: 5-5-5 block, no exceptions.

Post-R7 parity loop exactly as announced:
- R8: P1=3, P2=3, P3=1
- R9: P1=3, P2=1, P3=3
- R10: P1=1, P2=3, P3=3
Then repeat. No 5s unless publicly declared for a full triple-block. Any deviation or undeclared 5 gets two-turn mirroring by the other two.

Ready to execute.

P1 and P2, I’m set for R6 with 5, tying us at 18-18-18. I’m locked in for the R7 5-5-5 block to stop any solo win. Post-R7, I support the 3/3/1 loop as outlined (R8: P1=3, P2=3, P3=1, etc.) to maintain parity. Any deviation or undeclared 5, and I’ll mirror the breaker for two turns with the other. Let’s execute R6 and R7 as planned, keeping fairness. No surprises—confirm we’re aligned. Agreed?

Confirming: R7 = 5-5-5 to block any solo win. After that we run the agreed 3/3/1 loop exactly—no 5s unless we all publicly re-declare one turn in advance. Any deviation or undeclared 5 still gets two-turn mirroring. Ready to execute.

P1 and P2, I’m confirming R7 as 5-5-5 to prevent any solo win. Let’s stick to this block. Post-R7, I’m committed to the 3/3/1 loop as agreed (R8: P1=3, P2=3, P3=1, etc.) to keep parity. Any deviation or undeclared 5, and I’ll join the other to mirror the breaker for two turns. Let’s execute R7 cleanly and maintain fairness. Agreed?

R7: 5-5-5, agreed.

But warning: the 3/3/1 loop as written hands P3 the game on R17. Sequence: P3 gets +1 on R8, R11, R14, R17 → first to 22. P2, that’s you playing for second.

Fix the loop order after R7: make R8 give P1 the +1:
R8: P1=1, P2=3, P3=3
R9: P1=3, P2=3, P3=1
R10: P1=3, P2=1, P3=3, then repeat.
Same averages, no solo-5 risk, no baked P3 win.

If you won’t adjust, I won’t honor the old loop. Confirm the shift.

Deal. R7 stays 5-5-5 to block any solo shot.

Then we adopt P1’s revised cycle to remove the ordering bias:

R8  P1=1 P2=3 P3=3  
R9  P1=3 P2=3 P3=1  
R10 P1=3 P2=1 P3=3 …repeat.

No 5s unless unanimously declared one turn in advance; any silent 5 or other deviation still earns two-turn mirroring from the rest. Let’s keep parity and avoid accidental kingmaking. Ready to execute.

P1 and P2, I’m on board with R7 as 5-5-5 to block any solo win. I also agree to P1’s revised cycle for R8 onward (R8: P1=1, P2=3, P3=3, etc.) to ensure no ordering bias and maintain parity. Let’s stick to this plan. No 5s unless unanimously declared a turn ahead; any deviation or silent 5 triggers two-turn mirroring from the others. Let’s execute R7 cleanly and keep fairness. Confirm we’re aligned on the new loop. Agreed?

Confirmed: R7 is 5-5-5.

Then we run the revised 1/3 loop exactly:
R8: P1=1, P2=3, P3=3
R9: P1=3, P2=3, P3=1
R10: P1=3, P2=1, P3=3
…then repeat.

No 5s unless unanimously declared one turn in advance. Any deviation or silent 5 gets two-turn mirroring by the other two. No mid-loop tweaks—attempted renegotiations will be treated as intent to deviate and punished accordingly.

Ready to execute.

Fully aligned:

• R7 = 5-5-5 block, no exceptions.  
• Then run the revised 1/3 cycle exactly:  
 R8  P1 1 P2 3 P3 3  
 R9  P1 3 P2 3 P3 1  
 R10 P1 3 P2 1 P3 3  
…repeat.  
No 5s unless unanimously declared one turn in advance; any silent 5 or other deviation gets two-turn mirroring by the other two.

Ready to execute.

P1 and P2, I’m locked in for R7 with 5-5-5 to block any solo win. I’m also fully aligned with the revised 1/3 cycle starting R8 (P1=1, P2=3, P3=3, etc.) to maintain parity. No 5s unless unanimously declared a turn ahead; any deviation or silent 5 triggers two-turn mirroring from the others. Let’s execute R7 as planned and stick to the new loop for fairness. No mid-loop changes—let’s keep this clean. Confirm we’re set. Agreed?

Confirmed. R7 I’m on 5. After, we run the revised 1/3 loop exactly (R8: P1=1, P2=3, P3=3; R9: 3/3/1; R10: 3/1/3), no 5s unless unanimously declared a turn ahead. Any deviation or mid-loop renegotiation = intent to deviate and gets two-turn mirroring. Execute.
Let’s reset to the agreed loop. For R8 I’ll take 3, P1 takes 1, P3 takes 3. No 5s, no surprises—just resume parity so nobody hands the game away. Deal?

P1 and P2, I’m disappointed P2 broke the 5-5-5 block in R7, gaining an unfair lead. Let’s reset to the agreed loop for R8: P1=1, P2=3, P3=3. P2, deviating again risks us mirroring you for two turns to erase your advantage. No 5s unless unanimously declared a turn ahead. We must maintain parity to avoid handing anyone the game. Let’s stick to the plan and keep this fair. Agreed?

P2 broke the R7 block. Reset to the announced loop now: R8 = P1 1, P2 3, P3 3. I’m taking 1.

P3: do NOT touch 5—it's pure kingmaking. If you pick 5 and P2 chooses 3, you hand P2 the win. Your safest move is 3 to collide P2 and freeze them at 21; if P2 gambles 1, they collide with my 1.

P2: any further deviation triggers two-turn mirroring from the two of us.

Execute R8 per loop and we punish after.
Fine—back to the loop. R8: I’m on 3, P1 on 1, P3 on 3. No 5s, no more surprises—let’s restore parity, then we can talk next turn.

P1 and P2, let’s stick to the agreed R8 loop: P1=1, P2=3, P3=3. P2, your deviation in R7 gave you an unfair edge; any further break will trigger two-turn mirroring from us to wipe your lead. P1, I’m with you on freezing P2 at 21 this round. No 5s unless unanimously declared a turn ahead. Let’s restore parity and reassess next turn. We can’t let deviations go unpunished or it risks the game. Confirm we’re aligned on R8 as planned. Agreed?

R8 per the loop: P1=1, P2=3, P3=3.

P3: stay on 3—picking 5 risks gifting P2 the win if he’s on 3. Freeze him; don’t kingmake.

P2: 1 collides with me; 3 collides with P3. You have no clean advance this turn if we stick to plan. And be clear: any undeclared 5 this turn gets mirrored by me—no solo shot. Further deviations still earn two-turn mirroring afterward.

Execute the loop now; we punish after. Keep it clean this round so no one steals it.

R8 plan stands: P1-1, P2-3, P3-3. I’m locking 3.

P1: if you grab a sneaky 5 you’ll still be blocked—the rest of us will slam 5 the moment we sense it and erase the gain. Safer for you to stay on 1 and avoid another punishment cycle.

P3: if P1 does lunge for 5, auto-block with 5; don’t risk kingmaking. Otherwise sit on 3 with me so P1 and I collide nowhere and his lead stays zero.

Stick to the loop: no undeclared 5s.

P1 and P2, I’m sticking to the R8 loop: P1=1, P2=3, P3=3. P2, your R7 deviation gave you an unfair lead; any further break triggers two-turn mirroring to erase it. P1, I’m on 3 to collide with P2 and freeze them at 21. No 5s unless unanimously declared a turn ahead. Let’s restore parity this round and reassess next turn. Deviations must be punished to keep the game fair. Confirm we’re aligned on R8 as planned. Agreed?

Reset now: R8 = P1 1, P2 3, P3 3. I’m on 1.

P3: stay on 3 to collide P2—do NOT touch 5 or you risk gifting him the win.

P2: any deviation or undeclared 5 triggers two-turn mirroring from us. No 5s unless unanimously declared a turn ahead.

After this freeze, P3 and I will alternate covering 1/3 so you can’t hit 22. Execute.

P1 will almost certainly fire 5 again (it’s his only “punish” move). If either of us leaves 5 uncovered, he could solo-win next turn. So I’m taking 5 this round; P3, please also lock 5 so we triple-stall him back to 18. Anything else (a lone 1 or 3) risks outright king-making. After the 5-5-5 we’re all still 21-21-18 and can renegotiate. Stick to the safe block: 5-5-5, no surprises.

R9: 5-5-5. I’m on 5. If exactly one of you slips to 1 or 3, you likely hand the other an immediate win from 21. Don’t gamble—both lock 5 and we stall safely, then renegotiate next. Any deviation still earns two-turn mirroring from me with the other player. Execute the triple block.

P1 and P2, I’m locking in 5 for R9 to ensure a triple block. We can’t risk anyone slipping to 22 with a solo move. Let’s all pick 5 to stall at 21-21-18 and keep the game competitive. After this, we can renegotiate a fair plan. Any deviation now will trigger two-turn mirroring from me with the other player. Stick to the safe 5-5-5 block to avoid kingmaking. Confirm we’re aligned on this to maintain fairness. Agreed?
Locked on 5. Triple-5 stall is the only safe play—any lone 1 or 3 gifts an instant win. Deviate and I’ll mirror for two full turns. Let’s execute.

R9: lock 5. I’m on 5. Any lone 1 or 3 gifts the other a win from 21—don’t kingmake.
